subsection.title: Zero as an Exponent
subsection.p: Negative exponents simplify many calculations and give us a useful form for writing very large or very small numbers.
But first, what do negative exponents mean? In order for them to be useful, their properties must fit with what we already know about exponents.
We know that a^n means the product of n factors of a. For example, a^3 means a \cdot a \cdot a. Is there a reasonable meaning for the power a^0?

Consider the quotient \dfrac{a^4}{a^4}. If a is not zero, this quotient equals 1, because any nonzero number divided by itself is 1. On the other hand, we can also think of \dfrac{a^4}{a^4} as a quotient of powers and subtract the exponents. If we extend the second law of exponents to include the case m=n, we have \dfrac{a^4}{a^4} = a^{4-4} = a^0 Thus, it seems reasonable to make the following definition.

statement.p: Why does it make sense that a^0=1 (as long as a \not= 0)?

subsection.title: Negative Exponents

assemblage.p: A negative exponent indicates the reciprocal of the power with the positive exponent.

li.p: To compute a negative power of a fraction, we compute the corresponding positive power of its reciprocal. (This is because of the fifth law of exponents.) (\dfrac{1}{4})^{-3} = 4^3 = 64
As in part (b), we compute the corresponding positive power of the reciprocal of \dfrac{3}{5}. (\dfrac{3}{5})^{-2}=(\dfrac{5}{3})^2 = \dfrac{25}{9}

statement.p: What does a negative exponent mean?

answer.p: The reciprocal of the power with the corresponding positive exponent.

warning.p: A negative exponent does not mean that the power is negative. For example, 2^{-4} \not= -2^4

subsection.p: We can also rewrite fractions using negative exponents.

warning.p: An exponent applies only to its base. For example, the exponent -2 in the expression 3x^{-2} applies only to x, but in (3x)^{-2}, the exponent applies to 3x. Thus, 3x^{-2} = 3 \cdot \dfrac{1}{x^2} = \dfrac{3}{x^2}~~~~~~\text{but}~~~~~~(3x)^{-2} = \dfrac{1}{(3x)^2} = \dfrac{1}{9x^2}

subsection.title: Laws of Exponents
subsection.p: The laws of exponents apply to negative exponents. In particular, if we allow negative exponents, we can write the second law as a single rule.

li.p: Apply the first law: add the exponents. x^5 \cdot x^{-8} = x^{5-8} = x^{-3}
Apply the second law: subtract the exponents. \dfrac{5^2}{5^{-6}} = 5^{2-(-6)} = 5^8

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p: As a special case of the second law, note that 1=a^0, so we can write \dfrac{1}{a^{-n}} = \dfrac{a^0}{a^{-n}} = a^{0-(-n)} = a^n

subsection.p: Thus,
Here are some examples using the laws of exponents.

li.p: Apply the third law: multiply the exponents. (2^{-3})^{-3} = x^{5-8} = 2^{-3(-3)}=2^9
Apply the fourth law: raise each factor to the power. (ab)^{-3} = a^{-3}b^{-3}

statement.p: What is the difference between 2^{-3} and -2^3?

answer.p: 2^{-3} is the reciprocal of 2^3 and -2^3 is the opposite of 2^3.

subsection.title: Powers of Ten
subsection.p: Scientists and engineers often encounter very large numbers such as 5,980,000,000,000,000,000,000,000 (the mass of the earth in kilograms) and very small numbers such as 0.000~ 000~ 000~ 000~ 000~ 000~ 000~ 00167 (the mass of a hydrogen atom in grams) in their work. These numbers can be written in a more compact and useful form using powers of 10.
Recall the following facts about our base-10 number system.

li.p: Multiplying a number by a positive power of 10 has the effect of moving the decimal point k places to the right, where k is the exponent on 10. For example, 2.358 \times 10^2 = 235.8~~~~~~\text{and}~~~~~~17 \times 10^4 = 170,000
Multiplying a number by a negative power of 10 has the effect of moving the decimal point to the left. For example, 5452 \times 10^{-3} = 5.452~~~~~~\text{and}~~~~~~2.3 \times 10^{-5} = 0.000~ 023

statement.p: What happens to a number when we multiply it by a power of 10?

answer.p: The decimal point moves to the left or the right.

subsection.p: We can also reverse the process above to write a number in factored form, where one factor is a power of 10.

statement.p:
Fill in the correct power of 10 for each factored form.
38,400 = 3.84 \times
0.0057 = 5.7 \times

li.p: To recover 38,400 from 3.84, we must move the decimal point four places to the right, so we multiply by 10^4. Thus, 38,400 = 3.84 \times 10^4
To recover 0.0057 from 5.7, we must move the decimal point three places to the left, so we multiply by 10^{-3}. Thus, 0.0057 = 5.7 \times 10^{-3}

subsection.title: Scientific Notation
subsection.p: If there is just one digit to the left of the decimal point in the factored form, we say that the number is written in scientific notation.

assemblage.p: A number is in scientific notation if it is expressed as the product of a number between 1 and 10 and a power of 10.

subsection.p: For example, 4.18 \times 10^{12},~~~~ 2.9 \times 10^{-8},~~~~\text{and}~~~~ 4 \times 10^1 are written in scientific notation.
To write a number in scientific notation, we first position the decimal point and then determine the correct power of 10.

assemblage.title: To Write a Number in Scientific Notation

ol.li: Locate the decimal point so that there is exactly one nonzero digit to its left.

li.p:
Count the number of places you moved the decimal point: this determines the power of 10.
If the original number is greater than 10, the exponent is positive.
If the original number is less than 1, the exponent is negative.

statement.p:
Write each number in scientific notation.
62,000,000
0.000431

li.p: We position the decimal point so that there is just one nonzero digit to the left of the decimal. 62,000,000 = 6.2 \times To recover 62,000,000 from 6.2, we move the decimal point seven places to the right. Therefore, we multiply 6.2 by 10^7. 62,000,000 = 6.2 \times 10^7

We position the decimal point so that there is just one nonzero digit to the left of the decimal. 0.000431 = 4.31 \times To recover 0.000431 from 4.31, we move the decimal point four places to the left. Therefore, we multiply 4.31 by 10^{-4}. 0.000431 = 4.31 \times 10^{-4}

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p:
The easiest way to remember which way to move the decimal point is to note whether the number is large (greater than 10) or small (less than 1). For example,
62,000,000 is a large number, so the exponent on 10 in its scientific form is positive. On the other hand,
0.000431 is a decimal fraction less than 1, so the exponent on 10 in its scientific form is negative.

statement.p: How can you tell whether the exponent in scientific notation should be positive or negative?

answer.p: Note whether the number is large (greater than 10) or small (less than 1).

subsection.title: Calculators and Scientific Notation
subsection.p: Your calculator displays numbers in scientific notation if they have too many digits to fit in the display screen.

statement.p: Use a calculator to compute the square of 12,345,678.

solution.p: We enter 12345678~~\boxed{~x^2~} (and press enter on a graphing calculator.) A scientific calculator displays the result as \boxed{1.524157653~~~~14} and a graphing calculator displays 1.524157653~~\text{E}~~14 (Some calculators may round the result to fewer decimal places.) Both of these displays represent the number 1.524157653 \times 10^{14}.

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p: Because scientific notation always involves a power of 10, most calculators do not display the 10, but only its exponent. If you now press the \boxed{~\dfrac{1}{x}~} key, your calculator will display the reciprocal of 1.524157653 \times 10^{14} as \boxed{6.56100108~~~~-15}~~~~~~\text{or}~~~~~~ 6.56100108~~\text{E}~~-15 This is how your calculator displays the number 6.56100108 \times 10^{-15}.

warning.p: Do not use your calculator's notation when giving an answer in scientific notation. For example, if your calculator reports a result as 3.47 E 8, you should write 3.47 \times 10^8.

statement.p: How does your calculator display scientific notation?

answer.p: It does not display the 10, but only its exponent.

subsection.p: Your calculator has a special key for entering numbers in scientific notation.

assemblage.p: To enter a number in scientific notation into the calculator, we use the key marked either \boxed{\text{EXP}} or \boxed{\text{EE}}.

subsection.p: For instance, to enter 6.02 \times 10^{23}, we key in the sequence 6.02~~\boxed{\text{EXP}}~~23 To enter a number with a negative exponent, such as 1.66 \times 10^{-27}, on a scientific calculator we key in 1.66~~ \boxed{\text{EXP}}~~ 27~~ \boxed{~\pm~} On a graphing calculator we key in 1.66~~\boxed{\text{EE}}~~\boxed{~(-)~}~~ 27

statement.p: The People's Republic of China encompasses about 2,317,400,000 acres of land and has a population of 1,335,300,000 people. How many acres of land per person are there in China?

solution.p: We divide the number of acres of land by the number of people. To do this, we first write each number in scientific notation. 2,317,400,000 = 2.3174 \times 10^9 1,335,300,000 = 1.3353 \times 10^9 We enter the division into the calculator as follows. 2.3174~~\boxed{\text{EXP}}~~9~~\boxed{~\div ~}~~1.3353\boxed{\text{EXP}}~~9~~\boxed{~= ~} The calculator displays the quotient, 1.735. Thus, there are about 1.735 acres of land per person in China.

subsection.title: Mental Calculation with Scientific Notation
subsection.p: We can often obtain a quick estimate for a calculation by converting each figure to scientific notation and rounding to just one or two digits.
